medical: CC: Episodic mental status change and RUE numbness, and chorea (found on exam). HX: This 78y/o RHM was referred for an episode of unusual behavior and RUE numbness. In 9/91, he experienced near loss of consciousness, generalized weakness, headache and vomiting. Evaluation at that time revealed an serum glucose of >500mg/dL and he was placed on insulin therapy with subsequent resolution of his signs and symptoms. Since then, he became progressively more forgetful, and at the time of evaluation, 1/17/93, had lost his ability to perform his job repairing lawn mowers. His wife had taken over the family finances. He had also been "stumbling," when ambulating, for 2 months prior to presentation. He was noted to be occasionally confused upon awakening for last several months. On 1/15/93, he was lying on a couch when he suddenly began throwing pillows and blankets for no apparent reason. There had been no change in sleep, appetite, or complaint of depression. In addition, for two months prior to presentation, he had been experiencing 10-15minute episodes of RUE numbness. There was no face or lower extremity involvement. During the last year he had developed unusual movements of his extremities. MEDS: NPH Humulin 12U qAM and 6U qPM. Advil prn. PMH: 1) Traumatic amputation of the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. 2) Hospitalized for an unknown "nervous" condition in the 1940's. SHX/FHX: Retired small engine mechanic who worked in a poorly ventilated shop. Married with 13 children. No history of ETOH, Tobacco or illicit drug use. Father had tremors following a stroke. Brother died of brain aneurysm. No history of depression, suicide, or Huntington's disease in family. ROS: no history of CAD, Renal or liver disease, SOB, Chest pain, fevers, chills, night sweats or weight loss. No report of sign of bleeding. EXAM: BP138/63 HR65 RR15 36.1C MS: Alert and oriented to self, season; but not date, year, or place. Latent verbal responses and direction following. Intact naming, but able to repeat only simple but not complex phrases. Slowed speech, with mild difficulty with word finding. 2/3 recall at one minute and 0/3 at 3 minutes. Knew the last 3 presidents. 14/27 on MMSE: unable to spell "world" backwards. Unable to read/write for complaint of inability to see without glasses. CN: II-XII appeared grossly intact. EOM were full and smooth and without unusual saccadic pursuits. OKN intact. Choreiform movements of the tongue were noted. Motor: 5/5 strength throughout with Guggenheim type resistance. there were choreiform type movements of all extremities bilaterally. No motor impersistence noted. Sensory: unreliable. Cord: "normal" FNF, HKS, and RAM, bilaterally. Station: No Romberg sign. Gait: unsteady and wide-based. Reflexes: BUE 2/2, Patellar 2/2, Ankles Trace/Trace, Plantars were flexor bilaterally. Gen Exam: 2/6 Systolic ejection murmur in aortic area. COURSE: No family history of Huntington's disease could be elicited from relatives. Brain CT, 1/18/93: bilateral calcification of the globus pallidi and a high attenuation focus in the right occipital lobe thought to represent artifact. Carotid duplex, 1/18/93: RICA 0-15%, LICA 16-49% stenosis and normal vertebral artery flow bilaterally. Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE),1/18/93: revealed severe aortic fibrosis or valvular calcification with "severe" aortic stenosis in the face of "normal" LV function. Cardiology felt the patient the patient had asymptomatic aortic stenosis. EEG, 1/20/93, showed low voltage Delta over the left posterior quadrant and intermittent background slowing over the same region consistent with focal dysfunction in this quadrant. MRI Brain, 1/22/93: multiple focal and more confluent areas of increased T2 signal in the periventricular white matter, more prominent on the left; in addition, there were irregular shaped areas of increased T2 signal and decreased T1 signal in both cerebellar hemispheres; and age related atrophy; incidentally, there is a cavum septum pellucidum et vergae and mucosal thickening of the maxillary sinuses. Impression: diffuse bilateral age related ischemic change, age related atrophy and maxillary sinus disease. There were no masses or areas of abnormal enhancement. TSH, FT4, Vit B12, VDRL, Urine drug and heavy metal screens were unremarkable. CSF,1/19/93: glucose 102 (serum glucose 162mg/dL), Protein 45mg/dL, RBC O, WBC O, Cultures negative. SPEP negative. However serum and CSF beta2 microglobulin levels were elevated at 2.5 and 3.1mg/L, respectively. Hematology felt these may have been false positives. CBC, 1/17/93: Hgb 10.4g/dL (low), HCT 31% (low), RBC 3/34mil/mm3 (low), WBC 5.8K/mm3, Plt 201K/mm3. Retic 30/1K/mm3 (normal). Serum Iron 35mcg/dL (low), TIBC 201mcg/dL (low), FeSat 17% (low), CRP 0.1mg/dL (normal), ESR 83mm/hr (high). Bone Marrow Bx: normal with adequate iron stores. Hematology felt the finding were compatible with anemia of chronic disease. Neuropsychologic evaluation on 1/17/93 revealed significant impairments in multiple realms of cognitive function (visuospatial reasoning, verbal and visual memory, visual confrontational naming, impaired arrhythmatic, dysfluent speech marked by use of phrases no longer than 5 words, frequent word finding difficulty and semantic paraphasic errors) most severe for expressive language, attention and memory. The pattern of findings reveals an atypical aphasia suggestive of left temporo-parietal dysfunction. The patient was discharged1/22/93 on ASA 325mg qd. He was given a diagnosis of senile chorea and dementia (unspecified type). 6/18/93 repeat Neuropsychological evaluation revealed moderate decline in all areas tested reflecting severe dementia.
layman:
**Chief Complaint**  
The patient has had episodes of sudden changes in his mental state, numbness in his right arm, and involuntary jerky movements (chorea).

**History of Present Illness**  
A 78‑year‑old man was referred because of unusual behavior and right‑arm numbness. In September 1991 he nearly lost consciousness, felt very weak, had a headache and vomited. Blood work then showed a glucose level over 500 mg/dL; he was started on insulin and his symptoms resolved. Since that time his memory has gotten worse. By January 17 1993 he could no longer repair lawn mowers and his wife had taken over the family finances. For the two months before he came in he had been stumbling while walking and was sometimes confused when he woke up. On January 15 1993 he was lying on a couch when he suddenly threw pillows and blankets for no reason. He had no changes in sleep, appetite, or depression. For the last two months he had 10‑15‑minute episodes of numbness in his right arm; his face and legs were not involved. Over the past year he developed unusual movements of his limbs.

**Medications**  
- NPH Humulin 12 U in the morning, 6 U in the evening  
- Advil as needed  

**Past Medical History**  
1. Amputation of the 4th and 5th fingers on his left hand after a trauma.  
2. Hospitalized in the 1940s for an unknown “nervous” condition.  

**Social / Family History**  
- Retired small‑engine mechanic who worked in a poorly ventilated shop.  
- Married with 13 children.  
- No alcohol, tobacco, or illegal drug use.  
- Father had tremors after a stroke; brother died of a brain aneurysm.  
- No family history of depression, suicide, or Huntington’s disease.  

**Review of Systems**  
No heart, kidney, or liver disease. No shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, chills, night sweats, or weight loss. No signs of bleeding.

**Physical Examination**  
- Blood pressure 138/63 mm Hg, heart rate 65 bpm, breathing 15/min, temperature 36.1 °C.  
- Mental status: alert, knows his name and the season but not the date, year, or place. Can repeat simple words but not longer phrases. Speech is slow with mild word‑finding difficulty. Memory recall is poor (2/3 at 1 min, 0/3 at 3 min). Knows the last three presidents. Scores 14/27 on the MMSE. Reports vision problems and cannot read or write without glasses.  
- Cranial nerves: all grossly intact. Eye movements normal. Tongue shows choreiform (jerky) movements.  
- Motor: 5/5 strength in all limbs, but choreiform movements in all limbs bilaterally. No weakness.  
- Sensory: unreliable.  
- Reflexes: normal in upper and lower limbs.  
- Gait: wide‑based and unsteady.  
- Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the aortic area.

**Course and Investigations**  
- No family history of Huntington’s disease.  
- Brain CT (Jan 18 1993): calcification in the basal ganglia (globus pallidus) and a high‑density spot in the right occipital lobe (likely an artifact).  
- Carotid duplex (Jan 18 1993): right internal carotid artery 0‑15% stenosis, left internal carotid 16‑49% stenosis, normal vertebral arteries.  
- Echocardiogram (Jan 18 1993): severe aortic valve calcification with severe aortic stenosis, but normal left‑ventricular function. Cardiology said the stenosis was asymptomatic.  
- EEG (Jan 20 1993): low‑voltage activity in the left posterior area, indicating focal dysfunction.  
- MRI brain (Jan 22 1993): multiple white‑matter changes, especially on the left; irregular areas in both cerebellar hemispheres; age‑related brain shrinkage; incidental cavum septum pellucidum and sinus thickening. No masses or abnormal enhancement.  
- Blood tests: normal thyroid, vitamin B12, VDRL, urine drug screen, heavy‑metal screen. CSF: glucose 102 mg/dL (serum glucose 162 mg/dL), protein 45 mg/dL, no red or white cells, cultures negative. Serum and CSF beta‑2 microglobulin slightly high (2.5 and 3.1 mg/L) – hematology thought these might be false positives.  
- CBC (Jan 17 1993): hemoglobin 10.4 g/dL (low), hematocrit 31% (low), red cells 3.34 million/mm³ (low), white cells 5.8 k/mm³, platelets 201 k/mm³, reticulocytes 30 k/mm³ (normal). Iron studies: serum iron 35 µg/dL (low), total iron‑binding capacity 201 µg/dL (low), transferrin saturation 17% (low). CRP 0.1 mg/dL (normal), ESR 83 mm/hr (high). Bone‑marrow biopsy normal with adequate iron stores – consistent with anemia of chronic disease.  
- Neuropsychological evaluation (Jan 17 1993): significant deficits in visual‑spatial reasoning, verbal and visual memory, naming, and expressive language. Speech was dysfluent, using short phrases, with frequent word‑finding problems. The pattern suggested left‑temporal‑parietal dysfunction.  
- Diagnosis: senile chorea and unspecified dementia.  
- Discharged (Jan 22 1993) on aspirin 325 mg daily.  
- Follow‑up neuropsychological test (June 18 1993) showed moderate decline in all areas, indicating severe dementia.

**Summary**  
The patient has progressive memory loss, confusion, and involuntary jerky movements. Imaging shows age‑related brain changes and aortic valve disease. Blood work indicates anemia of chronic disease. He was diagnosed with senile chorea and unspecified dementia, and his condition has worsened over time.
